This parameter is normally controlled by SearchInterface.options.allowEmptyQuery option.

name: QueryBuilder.categoryFacets
comment: Specifies an array of request for the CategoryFacet component.

name: QueryBuilder.childField
comment: Specifies the childField when doing parent-child loading (See: Folding).

name: QueryBuilder.commerce
comment: A request for a commerce query.

name: QueryBuilder.constantExpression
comment: Used to build the advanced part of the query expression. This part is similar to advancedExpression, but its content is interpreted as a constant expression by the index and it takes advantage of special caching features.

name: QueryBuilder.context
comment: The custom context information to send along with the query. Each value should be a string or an array of strings. Custom context information can influence the output of Coveo Machine Learning models and can also be used in query pipeline conditions.

name: QueryBuilder.disjunctionExpression
comment:
Used to build the disjunctive part of the query expression. When present, this part is evaluated separately from the other expressions and the matching results are merged to those matching expressions, advancedExpression and constantExpression.

The final boolean expression for the query is thus (basic advanced constant) OR (disjunction).

name: QueryBuilder.enableCollaborativeRating
comment:
Note:

The Coveo Cloud V2 platform does not support collaborative rating. Therefore, this property is obsolete in Coveo Cloud V2.

Whether the index should take collaborative rating in account when ranking result (See: ResultRating).

name: QueryBuilder.enableDebug
comment:
Whether to enable debug info on the query. This will return additional information on the resulting JSON response from the Search API.

Mostly: execution report (a detailed breakdown of the parsed and executed query).

name: QueryBuilder.enableDidYouMean
comment: Whether to enable query corrections on this query (see DidYouMean).

name: QueryBuilder.enableLowercaseOperators
comment:
Whether to interpret the AND, NOT, OR, and NEAR keywords in the basic expression as query operators, even if those keywords are in lowercase. Setting this attribute to true has no effect unless enableQuerySyntax is also true.

Note:

Normally, the enableLowercaseOperators option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.enablePartialMatch
comment:
Whether to automatically convert the basic expression to a partial match expression if it contains at least a certain number of keywords (see partialMatchKeywords), so that items containing at least a certain subset of those keywords (see partialMatchThreshold) will match the query. Note:

Normally, the enablePartialMatch option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.enableQuerySyntax
comment:
Whether to interpret special query syntax (e.g., @objecttype=message) in the basic expression (see Coveo Query Syntax Reference). See also enableLowercaseOperators.

Note:

Normally, the enableQuerySyntax option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page. End user preferences can also modify the value of this attribute.

Default value is false

name: QueryBuilder.enableQuestionMarks
comment:
Whether to interpret question mark characters (?) in the basic expression keywords (see Using Wildcards in Queries. Setting this attribute to true has no effect unless enableWildcards is also true.

Note:

Normally, the enableQuestionMarks option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.enableWildcards
comment:
Whether to interpret wildcard characters (*) in the basic expression keywords. Setting this attribute to true enables the wildcards features of the index, effectively expanding keywords containing wildcard characters (*) to the possible matching keywords in order to broaden the query (see Using Wildcards in Queries).

See also enableQuestionMarks.

Note:

Normally, the enableWildcards option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.excerptLength
comment:
Specifies the length (in number of characters) of the excerpts generated by the indexer based on the keywords present in the query. The index includes the top most interesting sentences (in the order they appear in the item) that fit in the specified number of characters.

When not specified, the default value is 200.

name: QueryBuilder.expression
comment: Used to build the basic part of the query expression. This part typically consists of user-entered content such as query keywords, etc.

name: QueryBuilder.facetOptions
comment: The global configuration options to apply to the requests in the facets array.

name: QueryBuilder.facetRequests
comment: Specifies an array of request for the DynamicFacet component. Cannot be used alongside groupByRequests

name: QueryBuilder.filterField
comment:
Specifies a field on which Folding should be performed. Folding is a kind of duplicate filtering where only the first result with any given value of the field is included in the result set.

It's typically used to return only one result in a conversation, for example when forum posts in a thread are indexed as separate items.

name: QueryBuilder.filterFieldRange
comment: Number of results that should be folded, using the IQuery.filterField.

name: QueryBuilder.firstResult
comment: This is the 0-based index of the first result to return. If not specified, this parameter defaults to 0.

name: QueryBuilder.groupByRequests
comment: Specifies an array of Group By operations that can be performed on the query results to extract facets. Cannot be used alongside facetRequests

name: QueryBuilder.longQueryExpression
comment: The contextual text. This is the contextual text part of the query. It uses the Coveo Machine Learning service to pick key keywords from the text and add them to the basic expression. This field is mainly used to pass context such a case description, long textual query or any other form of text that might help in refining the query.

name: QueryBuilder.maximumAge
comment:
The maximum age for cached query results, in milliseconds. If results for the exact same request (including user identities) are available in the in-memory cache, they will be used if they are not older than the specified value.

Otherwise, the query will be sent to the index.

name: QueryBuilder.numberOfResults
comment: This is the number of results to return, starting from IQuery.firstResult. If not specified, this parameter defaults to 10.

name: QueryBuilder.parentField
comment: Specifies the parentField when doing parent-child loading (See: Folding).

name: QueryBuilder.partialMatchKeywords
comment:
The minimum number of keywords that need to be present in the basic expression to convert it to a partial match expression. The value of this attribute has no meaning unless enablePartialMatch is true.

See also partialMatchThreshold.

Note:

Normally, the partialMatchKeywords option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.partialMatchThreshold
comment:
An absolute or relative (percentage) value indicating the minimum number of partial match expression keywords an item must contain to match the query. The value of this attribute has no meaning unless enablePartialMatch is true.

See also partialMatchKeywords.

Note:

Normally, the partialMatchThreshold option of the Querybox component determines the value of this attribute during the initialization of the search page.

name: QueryBuilder.pipeline
comment: Name of the query pipeline to use. Specifies the name of the query pipeline to use for the query. If not specified, the default value is default, which means the default query pipeline will be used.

name: QueryBuilder.queryFunctions
comment: Specifies an array of Query Function operation that will be executed on the results.

name: QueryBuilder.rankingFunctions
comment: Specifies an array of Ranking Function operations that will be executed on the results.

name: QueryBuilder.recommendation
comment: This is the ID of the recommendation interface that generated the query.

name: QueryBuilder.searchHub
comment: The hub value set from the Analytics component. Used for analytics reporting in the Coveo platform.

name: QueryBuilder.sortCriteria
comment:
Specifies the sort criterion(s) to use to sort results. If not specified, this parameter defaults to relevancy. Possible values are :
-- relevancy : This uses all the configured ranking weights as well as any specified ranking expressions to rank results.
-- dateascending / datedescending Sort using the value of the @date field, which is typically the last modification date of an item in the index.
-- qre : Sort using only the weights applied through ranking expressions. This is much like using relevancy except that automatic weights based on keyword proximity etc, are not computed.
-- nosort : Do not sort the results. The order in which items are returned is essentially random.
-- @field ascending / @field descending Sort using the value of a custom field.

name: QueryBuilder.tab
comment: The tab value set from the Tab component.

name: QueryBuilder.userActions
comment: A request to retrieve user actions in the query response.

name: QueryController
comment:
This class is automatically instantiated and bound to the root of your search interface when you initialize the framework.
It is essentially a singleton that wraps the access to the SearchEndpoint endpoint to execute query, and is in charge of triggering the different query events.
This is what every component of the framework uses internally to execute query or access the endpoint.
When calling Coveo.executeQuery this class is used.

name: QueryController.disabled
comment: A disabled component will not participate in the query, or listen to ComponentEvents.

name: QueryController.logger
comment: Allows component to log in the dev console.

name: QueryController.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component needs in order to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID: SearchButton -> className: CoveoSearchButton

name: QueryController.constructor
comment: Create a new query controller

name: QueryEvents
comment: This static class is there to contains the different string definition for all the events related to query. Note that these events will only be triggered when the QueryController.executeQuery method is used, either directly or by using executeQuery

name: QueryEvents.buildingQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is being built. This is typically where all components will contribute their part to the IQuery using the QueryBuilder.

All bound handlers will receive IBuildingQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is buildingQuery.

name: QueryEvents.deferredQuerySuccess
comment:
Triggered after the main query success event has finished executing. This is typically where facets will process the IGroupByResult and render themselves.

All bound handlers will receive IQuerySuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is deferredQuerySuccess.

name: QueryEvents.doneBuildingQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is done being built. This is typically where the facet will add it's IGroupByRequest to the IQuery.

All bound handlers will receive IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is doneBuildingQuery.

name: QueryEvents.duringFetchMoreQuery
comment:
Triggered when more results are being fetched on the Search API (think : infinite scrolling, or pager). All bound handlers will receive IDuringQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is duringFetchMoreQuery.

name: QueryEvents.duringQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is being executed on the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IDuringQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is duringQuery.

name: QueryEvents.fetchMoreSuccess
comment:
Triggered when a more results were successfully returned from the Search API. (think : infinite scrolling, or pager). All bound handlers will receive IFetchMoreSuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is fetchMoreSuccess.

name: QueryEvents.newQuery
comment:
Triggered when a new query is launched. All bound handlers will receive INewQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is newQuery.

name: QueryEvents.noResults
comment:
Triggered when there is no result for a particular query. All bound handlers will receive INoResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is noResults.

name: QueryEvents.preprocessMoreResults
comment:
Triggered before the QueryEvents.fetchMoreSuccess event. This allows external code to modify the results before rendering them.

For example, the Folding component might use this event to construct a coherent parent child relationship between query results.

All bound handlers will receive IPreprocessResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is preprocessMoreResults.

name: QueryEvents.preprocessResults
comment:
Triggered before the QueryEvents.querySuccess event. This allows external code to modify the results before rendering them.

For example, the Folding component might use this event to construct a coherent parent child relationship between query results.

All bound handlers will receive IPreprocessResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is preprocessResults.

name: QueryEvents.queryError
comment:
Triggered when there was an error executing a query on the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IQueryErrorEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is queryError.

name: QueryEvents.querySuccess
comment:
Triggered when a query successfully returns from the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IQuerySuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is querySuccess.

name: QueryStateModel
comment:
The QueryStateModel class is a key-value store which contains the current state of the components that can affect the query (see State). This class inherits from the Model class. Optionally, it is possible to persist the state in the query string in order to enable browser history management (see the HistoryController class). Components set values in the QueryStateModel instance to reflect their current state. The QueryStateModel triggers state events (see eventTypes) whenever one of its values is modified. Components listen to triggered state events to update themselves when appropriate.

For instance, when a query is triggered, the Searchbox component sets the q attribute (the basic query expression), while the Pager component sets the first attribute (the index of the first result to display in the result list), and so on.

Example:

The user modifies the content of the Searchbox and submits a query. This triggers the following state events:

  • state:change:q (because the value of q has changed).
  • state:change (because at least one value has changed in the QueryStateModel).

Components or external code can attach handlers to those events:

Coveo.$$(document).on('state:change:q', function() {
  [ ... ]
});

Note:

Normally, you should interact with the QueryStateModel instance using the Coveo.state top-level function.

name: QueryStateModel.attributes
comment:
The attributes contained in this model.
Normally, you should not set attributes directly on this property, as this would prevent required events from being triggered.

name: QueryStateModel.disabled
comment: A disabled component will not participate in the query, or listen to ComponentEvents.

name: QueryStateModel.logger
comment: Allows component to log in the dev console.

name: QueryStateModel.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component needs in order to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID: SearchButton -> className: CoveoSearchButton

name: QueryStateModel.eventTypes
comment:
The event types that can be triggered:
preprocess: triggered before a value is set on an attribute. This allows the value to be modified before it is set.
changeOne: triggered when a single value changes.
change: triggered when one or many values change.
reset: triggered when all attributes are reset to their default values.
all: triggered after the change event.

name: QueryStateModel.constructor
comment: Creates a new QueryStateModel instance.

name: QuerySummaryEvents
comment: This static class is there to contains the different string definition for all the events related to the AdvancedSearch component.

name: QuerySummaryEvents.cancelLastAction
comment: Triggered when the last action is being cancelled by the query summary component Allows external code to revert their last action.

name: QuickviewEvents
comment: The QuickviewEvents static class contains the string definitions of all events that strongly relate to the Quickview component.

name: QuickviewEvents.openQuickview
comment:
Triggered by the QuickviewDocument component when the end user has just clicked the Quickview button/link to open the quickview modal window. This event allows external code to modify the terms to highlight before the content of the quickview modal window is rendered.

All openQuickview event handlers receive an OpenQuickviewEventArgs object as an argument.

name: QuickviewEvents.quickviewLoaded
comment:
Triggered by the QuickviewDocument component when the content to display in the quickview modal window has just finished downloading. The Quickview component listens to this event to know when to remove its loading animation.

All quickviewLoaded event handlers receive a QuickviewLoadedEventArgs object as an argument.

name: RadioButton
comment: A radio button widget with standard styling.

name: RadioButton.constructor
comment: Creates a new RadioButton.

name: ResponsiveComponents
comment:
This class serves as a way to get and set the different screen size breakpoints for the interface. By setting those, you can impact, amongst others, the Facet's, Tab's or the ResultList's behaviour.

For example, the Facet components of your interface will switch to a dropdown menu when the screen size reaches 800px or less.

You could modify this value using this calls

Normally, you would interact with this class using the instance bound to SearchInterface.responsiveComponents

name: ResultListEvents
comment: The ResultListEvents static class contains the string definitions of all events that strongly relate to the result list. See Events.

name: ResultListEvents.changeLayout
comment: Triggered by the ResultLayout component whenever the current result layout changes (see Result Layouts). All changeLayout event handlers receive a ChangeLayoutEventArgs object as an argument.

name: ResultListEvents.newResultDisplayed
comment: Triggered each time the result list has just finished rendering a single result. All newResultDisplayed event handlers receive a DisplayedNewResultEventArgs object as an argument.

name: ResultListEvents.newResultsDisplayed
comment: Triggered when the result list has just finished rendering the current page of results.

name: ResultListEvents.openQuickview
comment:
Triggered by the ResultLink result template component when its openQuickview option is set to true and the end user clicks the result link. The Quickview component listens to this event to be able to open the quickview modal window in reaction. See also the openQuickview event (which is identical to this one, except that it is triggered by the [QuickviewDocument] result template component instead).

All openQuickview event handlers receive an OpenQuickviewEventArgs object as an argument

name: ResultPreviewsManagerEvents
comment: Those are the string definitions of events for ResultPreviewsManager. Those events should be bound to the element returned by resolveRoot.

name: ResultPreviewsManagerEvents.buildingResultPreviewsQuery
comment: Executed when building a query to fetch result previews. This always receives IBuildingResultPreviewsQueryEventArgs as arguments.

name: ResultPreviewsManagerEvents.populateSearchResultPreviews
comment: Executed when a Suggestion is focused and waiting for search result previews. This always receives IPopulateSearchResultPreviewsEventArgs as arguments.

name: ResultPreviewsManagerEvents.updateResultPreviewsManagerOptions
comment: Executed when a Suggestion is focused before PopulateSearchResultPreviews is called to fetch more options. This always receives IUpdateResultPreviewsManagerOptionsEventArgs as arguments.

name: SearchEndpoint
comment:
The SearchEndpoint class allows the framework to perform HTTP requests against the Search API (e.g., searching, getting query suggestions, getting the HTML preview of an item, etc.). Note:

When writing custom code that interacts with the Search API, be aware that executing queries directly through an instance of this class will not trigger any query events.

In some cases, this may be what you want. However, if you do want query events to be triggered (e.g., to ensure that standard components update themselves as expected), use the queryController instance instead.

name: SearchEndpoint.endpoints
comment: A map of all initialized SearchEndpoint instances. Example: Coveo.SearchEndpoint.endpoints["default"] returns the default endpoint that was created at initialization.

name: SearchEndpoint.constructor
comment: Creates a new SearchEndpoint instance. Uses a set of adequate default options, and merges these with the options parameter. Also creates an EndpointCaller instance and uses it to communicate with the endpoint internally.

name: StandaloneSearchInterfaceEvents
comment: The StandaloneSearchInterfaceEvents static class contains the string definitions of all events that strongly relate to the standalone search interface.

name: StandaloneSearchInterfaceEvents.beforeRedirect
comment: Triggered by the StandaloneSearchBox component during initialization, just before redirecting to the full search page.

name: StaticPositionProvider
comment: The StaticPositionProvider class provides a static end user position to a DistanceResources component.

name: TemplateCache
comment: Holds a reference to all template available in the framework

name: TemplateHelpers
comment: Allow to register and return template helpers (essentially: Utility functions that can be executed in the context of a template to render complex elements).

name: TextInput
comment: A text input widget with standard styling.

name: TextInput.constructor
comment: Creates a new TextInput.

name: IAdvancedSearchSection
comment: Describe a section in the AdvancedSearch component

name: IAdvancedSearchSection.inputs
comment: The array of inputs to populate. External code should only push inputs that match the type BaseFormTypes.

name: IAdvancedSearchSection.name
comment: The name of the section.

name: IAnalyticsActionCause
comment: The IAnalyticsActionCause interface describes the cause of an event for the analytics service. See the Analytics component

name: IAnalyticsActionCause.name
comment: Specifies the name of the event. While you can actually set this property to any arbitrary string value, its value should uniquely identify the precise action that triggers the event. Thus, each individual event should have its own unique name value. Example: searchBoxSubmit, resultSort, etc.

name: IAnalyticsActionCause.type
comment: Specifies the type of the event. While you can actually set this property to any arbitrary string value, it should describe the general category of the event. Thus, more than one event can have the same type value, which makes it possible to group events with identical types when doing reporting. Example: All search box related events could have searchbox as their type value.

name: IAnalyticsClickQuerySuggestPreviewMeta
comment: Describes the object sent as metadata along with clickQuerySuggestPreview usage analytics events.

name: IAnalyticsClickQuerySuggestPreviewMeta.displayedRank
comment: The 0-based position of the preview item that was opened.

name: IAnalyticsClickQuerySuggestPreviewMeta.suggestion
comment: The query suggestion for which a preview item was opened.

name: IAnalyticsClient
comment: The IAnalyticsClient interface describes an analytics client that can log events to, or return information from the usage analytics service. See also the Analytics component.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewEventArgs
comment: The IAnalyticsDocumentViewEventArgs interface describes the object that all documentViewEvent handlers receive as an argument.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewEventArgs.documentViewEvent
comment: The data to send in the request body of the Usage Analytics Write REST API call that logs the click event.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta
comment: The IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta interface describes the expected metadata when logging a click event / item view. See also the Analytics component, and more specifically its logClickEvent method.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.author
comment: The author of the clicked item.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.documentTitle
comment: The title of the clicked item.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.documentURL
comment: The URL of the clicked item.

name: IAnalyticsEvent
comment: The common subset of fields used to describe Coveo Cloud usage analytics _search_, [_click_](@link IClickEvent), and [_custom_](@link ICustomEvent) events.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.actionCause
comment:
A unique name describing the action that triggered the event. See the name property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: pagerNext

name: IAnalyticsEvent.actionType
comment:
A name describing the category of actions to which the action that triggered the event belongs. See the type property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: getMoreResults

name: IAnalyticsEvent.anonymous
comment: Whether the event should be logged anonymously to the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service. Note: This field is normally set to the anonymous option value of the Analytics component.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.clientId
comment: A GUID representing the current user. This GUID is generated locally and stored in a non-expiring browser cookie.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.customData
comment:
Additional metadata to send along with the event. Note: This field may include custom user context information (see Sending Custom Context Information).

Example: { "currentResultsPerPage": 25, "userRole": "developer" }

name: IAnalyticsEvent.device
comment:
The name of the device or browser that triggered the event. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Chrome

name: IAnalyticsEvent.language
comment:
The language of the search interface from which the event originates. Must be a valid ISO-639-1 code.

Note: By default, the framework sets this field according to the currently loaded culture file (see Changing the Language of Your Search Interface).

Example: en

name: IAnalyticsEvent.mobile
comment: Whether the event originates from a mobile device. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.originContext
comment:
The broad application context from which the event originates. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to Search. However, you can use the setOriginContext method of the Analytics component to modify the default value.

Example: Search

name: IAnalyticsEvent.originLevel1
comment:
The identifier of the search interface from which the event originates. Note: This field is normally set through the searchHub option of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: PartnerPortalSearch

name: IAnalyticsEvent.originLevel2
comment:
The identifier of the tab from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the identifier of the currently selected Tab in the search interface.

Example: All

name: IAnalyticsEvent.originLevel3
comment:
The address of the webpage that linked to the search interface from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the current document.referrer value.

Example: http://example.com/

name: IAnalyticsEvent.responseTime
comment: The time it took to get a response from the Search API for the query related to the event (in milliseconds). Note: The framework normally sets this field to 0, except for search events in which case it sets the field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.userAgent
comment:
The software acting on behalf of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.100 Safari/537.36

name: IAnalyticsEvent.userDisplayName
comment:
The display name of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the userDisplayName option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: Alice Smith

name: IAnalyticsEvent.userGroups
comment: The groups the end-user whose action triggered the event belongs to. Note: This field is normally left undefined, and the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service attempts to extract the information from the search token when actually recording the event.

name: IAnalyticsEvent.username
comment:
The identifier of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the user option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: asmith@example.com

name: IAnalyticsEventArgs
comment: The object that all analyticsEventReady handlers receive as an argument.

name: IAnalyticsEventArgs.coveoAnalyticsEventData
comment: The fields describing the Coveo Cloud usage analytics event.

name: IAnalyticsEventArgs.event
comment: The type of Coveo Cloud usage analytics event.

name: IAnalyticsFacetState
comment: Describes the current condition of a single dynamic facet value.

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.displayValue
comment: The custom display name of the dynamic facet value that was interacted with. Example: Alice R. Smith

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.end
comment:
The maximum value of the dynamic range facet value. Examples:

  • 500
  • 2018-12-31T23:59:59.999Z

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.endInclusive
comment: Whether the end value is included in the dynamic range facet value.

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.facetType
comment: The type of values displayed in the dynamic facet.

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.field
comment: The name of the field the dynamic facet displaying the value is based on. Example: author

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.id
comment: The unique identifier of the dynamic facet displaying the value. Example: author

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.start
comment:
The minimum value of the dynamic range facet value. Examples:

  • 0
  • 2018-01-01T00:00:00.000Z

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.state
comment: The new state of the dynamic facet value that was interacted with.

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.title
comment: The title of the dynamic facet. Example: Author

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.value
comment: The original name (i.e., field value) of the dynamic facet value. Example: alice_r_smith

name: IAnalyticsFacetState.valuePosition
comment: The current 1-based position of the dynamic facet value, relative to other values in the same dynamic facet.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions
comment: Options for building an <a> tag.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.class
comment: The CSS class(es) of the tag.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.target
comment: The target (href attribute).

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.text
comment: The tag's text content.

name: IBadgeColors
comment: Badge Colors

name: IBeforeRedirectEventArgs
comment: The IBeforeRedirectEventArgs interface describes the object that all beforeRedirect event handlers receive as an argument.

name: IBeforeRedirectEventArgs.cancel
comment: If this property is set to true by a beforeRedirect event handler, the StandaloneSearchBox component will not redirect to the full search page.

name: IBeforeRedirectEventArgs.searchPageUri
comment: The URI of the page that the search interface will redirect to when a query is performed by the StandaloneSearchBox component.

name: IBreadcrumbItem
comment: Represent an item to insert in the breadcrumb

name: IBreadcrumbItem.element
comment: The HTMLElement to insert in the breadcrumb

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on AdvancedSearchEvents.buildingAdvancedSearch

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs.executeQuery
comment: An easy way to execute a new query.

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs.sections
comment: Sections which external code can populate by pushing into this array.

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on QueryEvents.buildingQuery

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.cancel
comment: If this property is set to true by any handlers, the query will not be executed.

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.queryBuilder
comment: Allow handlers to modify the query by using the QueryBuilder

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.searchAsYouType
comment: Determine if the query is a "search-as-you-type"

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs
comment:
The IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs interface describes the object that all changeAnalyticsCustomData event handlers receive as an argument. This interface extends the IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject interface.

Notes:

  • External code can only modify the attributes described by the IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject interface.
  • When the analytics event being logged is a ClickEvent, the ChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs object also contains a resultData attribute, which describes the QueryResult that was clicked. External code cannot modify this object.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.actionCause
comment:
The cause of the usage analytics event. For instance, triggering a query using the search box logs a usage analytics event with searchBoxSubmit as its actionCause, whereas triggering a query by selecting a facet value logs a usage analytics event with facetSelect as its actionCause.

Note:

External code cannot modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.actionType
comment:
The generic action type of the usage analytics event. All analytics events that strongly relate to a certain feature or component usually share the same actionType.

For instance, all usage analytics events relating to the Facet component have facet as their actionType, whereas all usage analytics events relating to the Breadcrumb component have breadcrumb as their actionType.

Note:

External code cannot modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.language
comment:
The language of the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates. By default, the framework populates this attribute with the currently loaded localization and culture file of the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.metaObject
comment:
The metadata to send along with the usage analytics event. Note:

External code can modify existing values, or add new key-value pairs in this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel1
comment:
The high-level origin of the usage analytics event. For instance, this could be the name of the search hub, or a name that can uniquely identify the search page from which the usage analytics event originates.

Default value is default.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel2
comment:
The mid-level origin of the usage analytics event. By default, the framework populates this attribute with the data-id of the currently selected tab in the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel3
comment:
The low-level origin of the usage analytics event. For instance, this could be the HTTP identifier of the page from which the usage analytics event originates.

Default value is the empty string.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.type
comment:
The type of the usage analytics event. Note:

External code cannot modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeLayoutEventArgs
comment: The IChangeLayoutEventArgs interface describes the object that all ChangeLayout event handlers receive as an argument.

name: IChangeLayoutEventArgs.layout
comment: The name of the new layout.

name: IChangeLayoutEventArgs.results
comment: The current page of results.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject
comment: The IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject interface describes the modifiable part of the object that all changeAnalyticsCustomData event handlers receive as an argument.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.language
comment:
The language of the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates. By default, the framework populates this attribute with the currently loaded localization and culture file of the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.metaObject
comment:
The metadata to send along with the usage analytics event. Note:

External code can modify existing values, or add new key-value pairs in this attribute.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel1
comment:
The high-level origin of the usage analytics event. For instance, this could be the name of the search hub, or a name that can uniquely identify the search page from which the usage analytics event originates.

Default value is default.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel2
comment:
The mid-level origin of the usage analytics event. By default, the framework populates this attribute with the data-id of the currently selected tab in the search interface from which the usage analytics event originates.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel3
comment:
The low-level origin of the usage analytics event. For instance, this could be the HTTP identifier of the page from which the usage analytics event originates.

Default value is the empty string.

Note:

External code can modify the value of this attribute.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsMetaObject
comment: The IChangeableAnalyticsMetaObject interface describes the metadata which can be sent along with any usage analytics event.

name: IClickEvent
comment: Describes a Coveo Cloud usage analytics click event.

name: IClickEvent.actionCause
comment:
A unique name describing the action that triggered the event. See the name property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: pagerNext

name: IClickEvent.actionType
comment:
A name describing the category of actions to which the action that triggered the event belongs. See the type property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: getMoreResults

name: IClickEvent.anonymous
comment: Whether the event should be logged anonymously to the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service. Note: This field is normally set to the anonymous option value of the Analytics component.

name: IClickEvent.clientId
comment: A GUID representing the current user. This GUID is generated locally and stored in a non-expiring browser cookie.

name: IClickEvent.collectionName
comment:
The name of the collection to which the clicked query result item belongs. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: default

name: IClickEvent.customData
comment:
Additional metadata to send along with the event. Note: This field may include custom user context information (see Sending Custom Context Information).

Example: { "currentResultsPerPage": 25, "userRole": "developer" }

name: IClickEvent.device
comment:
The name of the device or browser that triggered the event. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Chrome

name: IClickEvent.documentCategory
comment:
The type of query result item that was clicked. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: FAQ

name: IClickEvent.documentPosition
comment: The 1-based position of the clicked item in the query results set. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

name: IClickEvent.documentTitle
comment:
The title of the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: Coveo ML Frequently Asked Questions

name: IClickEvent.documentUri
comment:
The URI of the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: http://www.example.com/org:organization/articletype:FAQ/article:aB1c2000000A1BcDEF/language:en_US

name: IClickEvent.documentUriHash
comment:
The hashed URI of the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: AbCdeFghiJKLM1n

name: IClickEvent.documentUrl
comment:
The URL of the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: https://example.com/aB1c2000000A1Bc

name: IClickEvent.language
comment:
The language of the search interface from which the event originates. Must be a valid ISO-639-1 code.

Note: By default, the framework sets this field according to the currently loaded culture file (see Changing the Language of Your Search Interface).

Example: en

name: IClickEvent.mobile
comment: Whether the event originates from a mobile device. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

name: IClickEvent.originContext
comment:
The broad application context from which the event originates. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to Search. However, you can use the setOriginContext method of the Analytics component to modify the default value.

Example: Search

name: IClickEvent.originLevel1
comment:
The identifier of the search interface from which the event originates. Note: This field is normally set through the searchHub option of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: PartnerPortalSearch

name: IClickEvent.originLevel2
comment:
The identifier of the tab from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the identifier of the currently selected Tab in the search interface.

Example: All

name: IClickEvent.originLevel3
comment:
The address of the webpage that linked to the search interface from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the current document.referrer value.

Example: http://example.com/

name: IClickEvent.queryPipeline
comment:
The name of the query pipeline to which the Search API query that returned the clicked result item was routed. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: PartnerPortalSearchPipeline

name: IClickEvent.rankingModifier
comment:
The ranking modifier that was applied to the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: Reveal ART

name: IClickEvent.responseTime
comment: The time it took to get a response from the Search API for the query related to the event (in milliseconds). Note: The framework normally sets this field to 0, except for search events in which case it sets the field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

name: IClickEvent.searchQueryUid
comment:
The unique identifier of the Search API query that returned the clicked result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: 74682726-0e20-46eb-85ac-f37259346f57

name: IClickEvent.sourceName
comment:
The name of the source that contains the clicked query result item. Note: The framework normally sets this field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

Example: Product Documentation

name: IClickEvent.splitTestRunName
comment:
The name of the A/B test that applied to the related Search API query. Note: This field is normally set by the splitTestRunName option of the Analytics component. However, if this option is left undefined, the framework attempts to set this field by retrieving information from the related Search API query response.

Example: Testing new ART model

name: IClickEvent.splitTestRunVersion
comment:
The version of the A/B test that applied to the related Search API query (i.e., version A or version B). Note: This field is normally set by the splitTestRunVersion option of the Analytics component. However, if this option is left undefined and the related Search API query response indicates that an A/B test was applied, the framework sets this field to the name of the query pipeline to which the query was routed.

Example: PartnerPortalSearchPipelineWithART

name: IClickEvent.userAgent
comment:
The software acting on behalf of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.100 Safari/537.36

name: IClickEvent.userDisplayName
comment:
The display name of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the userDisplayName option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: Alice Smith

name: IClickEvent.userGroups
comment: The groups the end-user whose action triggered the event belongs to. Note: This field is normally left undefined, and the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service attempts to extract the information from the search token when actually recording the event.

name: IClickEvent.username
comment:
The identifier of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the user option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: asmith@example.com

name: IClickEvent.viewMethod
comment:
The way the item was clicked. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the exact same value as actionCause.

Example: documentOpen

name: ICommerceRequest
comment: A Search API commerce request.

name: ICommerceRequest.catalogId
comment: The unique identifier of the catalog to query. Example: 46bc4275-e613-4dd5-b1ea-3e5aca1bcd9d

name: ICommerceRequest.filter
comment: A mandatory query expression to apply if the commerce request affects the query. Example: @storeid==1001

name: ICommerceRequest.operation
comment: The way the commerce request should affect query results. Example: selectCatalogObjects

name: IComponentBindings
comment: The bindings, or environment in which each component exists.

name: IComponentBindings.componentOptionsModel
comment: Contains the state of options for different components. Mainly used by ResultLink.

name: IComponentBindings.componentStateModel
comment: Contains the state of different components (enabled vs disabled). Allows to get/set values. Triggers component state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: IComponentBindings.queryController
comment: Contains the singleton that allows to trigger queries.

name: IComponentBindings.queryStateModel
comment: Contains the state of the query. Allows to get/set values. Triggers state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: IComponentBindings.root
comment: The root HTMLElement of the SearchInterface in which the component exists.

name: IComponentBindings.searchInterface
comment: A reference to the root of every component, the SearchInterface.

name: IComponentBindings.usageAnalytics
comment: A reference to the Analytics.client.

name: IComponentDefinition
comment: Definition for a Component.

name: IComponentDefinition.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component need to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: IComponentDefinition.className
comment:
The generated className for this component.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: IComponentDefinition.doExport
comment: Function that can be called to export one or multiple module in the global scope.

name: IComponentDefinition.fields
comment: The optional index fields that the component possess or display.

name: IComponentDefinition.options
comment: The available options for the component.

name: IComponentDefinition.parent
comment: The optional parent of the component, which will be a component itself.

name: IComponentDefinition.constructor
comment: Constructor for each component

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs
comment: The IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs interface describes the available parameters when building a fields option.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.alias
comment:
Specifies an alias, or array of aliases, which can be used instead of the actual option name. Note:

This can be useful to modify an option name without introducing a breaking change.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.attrName
comment:
Specifies a different markup name to use for an option, rather than the standard name (i.e., data- followed by the hyphened name of the option). Note:

This should only be used for backward compatibility reasons.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.defaultFunction
comment: Specifies a function that should return the value the option must take when no other value is explicitly specified.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.depend
comment:
Specifies the name of a boolean component option which must be true in order for this option to function properly. Note:

This is mostly useful for the Coveo JavaScript Interface Editor.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.deprecated
comment:
Specifies a message that labels the option as deprecated. This message appears in the console upon initialization if the deprecated option is used in the page. Consequently, this message should explain as clearly as possible why the option is deprecated, and what now replaces it. Note:

Deprecated options do not appear in the Coveo JavaScript Interface Editor.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.postProcessing
comment:
Specifies a function that should allow a component option to further modify its own value once all other options of that component have been built. Example:

By default, the id option of the Facet component uses a post processing function to set its value to that of the field option.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.required
comment:
Specifies whether it is necessary to explicitly specify a value for the option in order for the component to function properly. Example:

The field option of the Facet component is required, since a facet cannot function properly without a field.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.section
comment: Specifies a section name inside which the option should appear in the Coveo JavaScript Interface Editor.

name: IComponentLocalizedStringOptionArgs.validator
comment: Specifies a function that should indicate whether the option value is valid.

name: IComputedFieldRequest
comment:
Describe a computed field request
See: Computed Fields

name: IComputedFieldRequest.field
comment: This specifies the field on which the aggregate operation will be performed. This field is typically a numerical value.

name: IComputedFieldRequest.operation
comment:
This specifies the operation to execute on the field value.
Possible operations: -- sum: Computes the sum of all values. -- average: Computes the average of all values. --minimum: Retrieves the smallest of all values. --maximum: Retrieves the largest of all values.

name: ICoreHelpers
comment:
The core template helpers provided by default. Examples:

HTML

<div class="CoveoFieldValue" data-field="@videoduration" data-helper="timeSpan" data-helper-options-is-milliseconds="false"></div>

Underscore

<%= timeSpan(raw.videoduration, { isMilliseconds: false }) %>

name: ICoreHelpers.anchor
comment:
Formats a clickable HTML link (<a>).

  • href: The link URI
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IAnchorUtilsOptions)

name: ICoreHelpers.currency
comment:
Formats a currency value to a string using the specified options.

  • content: The number value to format.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see ICurrencyToStringOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.date
comment:
Formats a date value to a date-only string using the specified options.

  • content: The Date value to format.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IDateToStringOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.dateTime
comment:
Formats a date value to a date and time string using the specified options.

  • content: The Date value to format.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IDateToStringOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.email
comment:
Renders one or several email values in mailto: hyperlinks.

  • value: The string or array of strings that contains a list of semicolon-separated email values. When multiple values are passed, each value is displayed in a separate hyperlink.
  • companyDomain: Optional. The string that contains your own domain (e.g.: coveo.com). When specified, this parameter allows email addresses coming from your own domain to be displayed in a shortened format (e.g.: Full Name), whereas email addresses coming from an external domain will be displayed in an extended format (e.g.: Full Name (domain.com)). If this parameter is not specified, then the shortened format will automatically be used.
  • me: Optional. The string that contains the current username. If it is specified, then the email address containing the current username will be replaced by the localized string 'Me'.
  • lengthLimit: Optional. The number of email addresses that you want to display before an ellipse is added (e.g.: 'From Joe, John and 5 others').
    The default value is 2.
  • truncateName: Optional. When the username is available from the email address, then you can specify if you want to truncate the full name. (e.g.: 'John S.' instead of 'John Smith').
    The default value is false.

name: ICoreHelpers.emailDateTime
comment:
Formats a date value to a date and time string using options suitable for email dates

  • content: The Date value to format.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IDateToStringOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.encodeCarriageReturn
comment:
Replace all carriage return in a string by a <br /> tag

  • value: The string value to replace the carriage returns in.

name: ICoreHelpers.fromFileTypeToIcon
comment:
Generates an icon based on the file type of the current result. The icon will be contained inside a <span> element with the appropriate CSS class.

  • result: Optional. The current result object inside your template. In underscore, it is referenced as obj. By default, the result will be resolved automatically from your current template function ( Meaning the nearest result in the current call stack execution inside your template)
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IIconOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.highlight
comment:
Highlights a string using the provided highlight information.

  • content: The URI to shorten.
  • highlights: Optional. The highlight information to use.
  • cssClass: Optional. The name of the CSS class to use for highlighting.

name: ICoreHelpers.highlightStreamHTML
comment:
This helper operates exactly like the highlightStreamText helper, except that it should be used to highlight HTML content. The helper takes care of not highlighting the HTML markup.

  • content: The string content to highlight
  • termsToHighlight: The terms to highlight (see IHighlightTerm)
  • phraseToHighlight: The phrases to highlight (see IHighlightPhrase)
  • options: Optional. The options defined below as IStreamHighlightOptions

Note:

highlightStreamHTML should only be used for very particular/specific use cases (e.g., augmenting the result template with additional information rather than the typical excerpt/title), and is not a proper replacement for actually having the correct title and excerpt on your results.

Using incorrect result titles or excerpts on your search interface also causes relevancy to suffer greatly, as the index uses the title and excerpt to find relevant results. Consequently, end users are more likely to see results whose titles do not match their query.

Moreover, the recommended method to implement simple title and/or excerpt highlighting is to simply use the Excerpt and ResultLink components.

name: ICoreHelpers.highlightStreamText
comment:
Highlights the provided terms in a given string.
By default, the terms to highlight are the current query and the associated stemming words from the index. The only required parameter is the content, which specify the string that needs to be highlighted. The other parameters will normally be automatically resolved for you from the current result object.

  • content: The string content to highlight
  • termsToHighlight: The terms to highlight (see IHighlightTerm)
  • phraseToHighlight: The phrases to highlight (see IHighlightPhrase)
  • options: Optional. The options defined below as IStreamHighlightOptions

Note:

highlightStreamText should only be used for very particular/specific use cases (e.g., augmenting the result template with additional information rather than the typical excerpt/title), and is not a proper replacement for actually having the correct title and excerpt on your results.

Using incorrect result titles or excerpts on your search interface also causes relevancy to suffer greatly, as the index uses the title and excerpt to find relevant results. Consequently, end users are more likely to see results whose titles do not match their query.

Moreover, the recommended method to implement simple title and/or excerpt highlighting is to simply use the Excerpt and ResultLink components.

name: ICoreHelpers.image
comment:
Formats an HTML image tag (<img>).

  • src: The image source URI
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IImageUtilsOptions)

name: ICoreHelpers.isMobileDevice
comment:
Detect if the results is being rendered in a mobile device. If it's not a mobile device, the helper return null ;

If it's a mobile device, return the type of device (Android, iPhone, iPad) etc.

name: ICoreHelpers.loadTemplate
comment:
Loads a partial template in the current template, by passing the ID of the template to load, the condition for which this template should be loaded, and the context object (the object that the loaded template will use as its data). By default, the context object will be the same as the template that called this helper function. So, for example, in a ResultList Component, the contextObject would, by default, be the Query Results.

  • templateId: The ID of the template to load.
  • condition: Optional. The boolean condition to determine if this template should load for this result set. Most of the time this would be a condition of the type if raw.somefield == 'something'.
  • contextObject: Optional. The object that should be used by the loaded template as its contextObject.

name: ICoreHelpers.number
comment:
Formats a numeric value using the format string.

  • content: The numeric value to format.
  • format Optional. The string format to use. See the Globalize library for the list of available formats.

When the helper is used in a FieldValue component, this value is automatically retrieved from the specified field.

Example:

 <div class="CoveoFieldValue" data-field="@viewcount" data-text-caption="Views" data-helper="number" data-helper-options-format="n0"></div>

name: ICoreHelpers.shorten
comment:
Shortens a string so that its length does not exceed a specific number of characters. An ellipsis is appended to the string if it exceeds the maximum length.

  • content: The string to shorten.
  • length: The maximum length of the resulting string.
  • highlights: Optional. If provided, the string will be highlighted using this highlight information.
  • cssClass: Optional. When highlighting, the name of the CSS class to use.

name: ICoreHelpers.shortenPath
comment:
Shortens a string using an algorithm suitable for file paths. The helper will insert an ellipsis in the string where text has been removed when the path exceeds the maximum length.

  • content: The path to shorten.
  • length: The maximum length of the resulting string.
  • highlights: Optional. If provided, the string will be highlighted using this highlight information.
  • cssClass: Optional. When highlighting, the name of the CSS class to use.

name: ICoreHelpers.shortenUri
comment:
Shortens a string using an algorithm suitable for URIs. The helper will insert an ellipsis in the string where text has been removed when the URI exceeds the maximum length.

  • content: The URI to shorten.
  • length: The maximum length of the resulting string.
  • highlights: Optional. If provided, the string will be highlighted using this highlight information.
  • cssClass: Optional. When highlighting, the name of the CSS class to use.

name: ICoreHelpers.size
comment:
Formats a number, which represents a file size in bytes, into a logical unit size. Examples:

size(1024) => 1024 B

size(1025) => 1 KB

size(10240) => 10 KB

Examples:

HTML

<div class="CoveoFieldValue" data-field='@size' data-helper="size" data-helper-options-base="1"></div>

Underscore

<%= size(raw.size, {base: 0, precision: 2}) %>
  • value: The number to format
  • options : The options to use (see ISizeOptions)

name: ICoreHelpers.thumbnail
comment:
Formats an HTML image tag (<img>), and automatically uses the result object to query the REST API to get the thumbnail for this result. For example, this can be used to great effect when designing a template showing users or previews of files.

  • result: Optional. The current result object inside your template. In underscore, it is referenced as obj. By default, the result will be resolved automatically from your current template function ( Meaning the nearest result in the current call stack execution inside your template)
  • endpoint: Optional. The name of the endpoint to use for your thumbnail. Default is default.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IImageUtilsOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.time
comment:
Formats a date value to a time-only string using the specified options.

  • content: The Date value to format.
  • options: Optional. The options to use (see IDateToStringOptions).

name: ICoreHelpers.timeSpan
comment:
Given a number, either in millisecond or second, convert to a HH:MM:SS format. Examples

timeSpan(1, {isMilliseconds: false}) => '00:01'

timeSpan(1000, {isMilliseconds: true}) => '00:01'

  • value: The number to convert to a timespan
  • options : The options to use (see ITimeSpanUtilsOptions)

name: ICoreHelpers.translatedCaption
comment:
Given a filetype value, try to return a translated and human readable version. If the filetype is known and recognized by the framework, a translated value will be returned.

Examples

translatedCaption('doc') => Document

translatedCaption('xls') => Spreadsheet Document

  • value: The string value to translate

name: ICurrencyToStringOptions
comment: The available options to format a numeric value as a currency string.

name: ICurrencyToStringOptions.decimals
comment: The number of decimals to display. Default: 0

name: ICurrencyToStringOptions.symbol
comment: The currency symbol to use.

name: ICustomEvent
comment: Describes a Coveo Cloud usage analytics custom event.

name: ICustomEvent.actionCause
comment:
A unique name describing the action that triggered the event. See the name property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: pagerNext

name: ICustomEvent.actionType
comment:
A name describing the category of actions to which the action that triggered the event belongs. See the type property of the IAnalyticsActionCause interface.

Example: getMoreResults

name: ICustomEvent.anonymous
comment: Whether the event should be logged anonymously to the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service. Note: This field is normally set to the anonymous option value of the Analytics component.

name: ICustomEvent.clientId
comment: A GUID representing the current user. This GUID is generated locally and stored in a non-expiring browser cookie.

name: ICustomEvent.customData
comment:
Additional metadata to send along with the event. Note: This field may include custom user context information (see Sending Custom Context Information).

Example: { "currentResultsPerPage": 25, "userRole": "developer" }

name: ICustomEvent.device
comment:
The name of the device or browser that triggered the event. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Chrome

name: ICustomEvent.eventType
comment:
A name describing the category of actions to which the action that triggered the event belongs. Note: Normally, this field is set to the same value as actionType.

Example: getMoreResults

name: ICustomEvent.eventValue
comment:
A unique name describing the action that triggered the event. Note: Normally, this field is set to the same value as actionCause.

Example: pagerNext

name: ICustomEvent.language
comment:
The language of the search interface from which the event originates. Must be a valid ISO-639-1 code.

Note: By default, the framework sets this field according to the currently loaded culture file (see Changing the Language of Your Search Interface).

Example: en

name: ICustomEvent.mobile
comment: Whether the event originates from a mobile device. Note: The framework normally sets this field by parsing the current navigator.userAgent value.

name: ICustomEvent.originContext
comment:
The broad application context from which the event originates. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to Search. However, you can use the setOriginContext method of the Analytics component to modify the default value.

Example: Search

name: ICustomEvent.originLevel1
comment:
The identifier of the search interface from which the event originates. Note: This field is normally set through the searchHub option of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: PartnerPortalSearch

name: ICustomEvent.originLevel2
comment:
The identifier of the tab from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the identifier of the currently selected Tab in the search interface.

Example: All

name: ICustomEvent.originLevel3
comment:
The address of the webpage that linked to the search interface from which the event originates. Note: The framework normally sets this field to the current document.referrer value.

Example: http://example.com/

name: ICustomEvent.responseTime
comment: The time it took to get a response from the Search API for the query related to the event (in milliseconds). Note: The framework normally sets this field to 0, except for search events in which case it sets the field by retrieving the information from the related Search API query response.

name: ICustomEvent.userAgent
comment:
The software acting on behalf of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: By default, the framework sets this field to the current navigator.userAgent value.

Example: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.100 Safari/537.36

name: ICustomEvent.userDisplayName
comment:
The display name of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the userDisplayName option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: Alice Smith

name: ICustomEvent.userGroups
comment: The groups the end-user whose action triggered the event belongs to. Note: This field is normally left undefined, and the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service attempts to extract the information from the search token when actually recording the event.

name: ICustomEvent.username
comment:
The identifier of the end-user whose action triggered the event. Note: This field is normally set to the user option value of the Analytics component. However, when actually recording the event, the Coveo Cloud usage analytics service may override this value with information extracted from the search token.

Example: asmith@example.com

name: IDateToStringOptions
comment: The IDateToStringOptions interface describes a set of options to use when converting a standard Date object to a string using the dateToString , or the dateTimeToString method from the DateUtils class. The precedence orders for the options are: useTodayYesterdayAndTomorrow -> useWeekdayIfThisWeek -> omitYearIfCurrentOne -> useLongDateFormat and alwaysIncludeTime -> includeTimeIfThisWeek -> includeTimeIfToday .

name: IDateToStringOptions.alwaysIncludeTime
comment:
Specifies whether to always include the time in the resulting string when converting the Date object (e.g. May 15, 4:17 PM) This option takes precedence over includeTimeIfThisWeek . Example

If includeTimeIfToday is true and now contains a Date object equivalent to Monday, March 8, 2017, then:

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to 2010/03/08 17:23:11, the resulting string is 3/8/2010, 5:23 PM.

Default value is false.

name: IDateToStringOptions.includeTimeIfThisWeek
comment:
Specifies whether to include the time in the resulting string when converting the Date object (e.g. May 15, 4:17 PM) if the date to convert within a week from now . This option takes precedence over includeTimeIfToday . Examples

If includeTimeIfToday is true and now contains a Date object equivalent to Monday, March 8, 2017, then:

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to 2017/03/08 17:23:11, the resulting string is 3/8/2017, 5:23 PM.

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to 2017/03/09 17:23:11, the resulting string is 3/9/2017 ,5:23 PM.

Default value is true.

name: IDateToStringOptions.includeTimeIfToday
comment:
Specifies whether to include the time in the resulting string when converting the Date object (e.g. May 15, 4:17 PM) if the date to convert is equivalent to now . Examples

If includeTimeIfToday is true and now contains a Date object equivalent to Monday, March 8, 2017, then:

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to 2017/03/08 17:23:11, the resulting string is 3/8/2017, 5:23 PM.

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to 2017/03/09 17:23:11, the resulting string is 3/9/2017.

Default value is true.

name: IDateToStringOptions.now
comment: Contains a standard Date object that specifies the current date and time. Default value is undefined.

name: IDateToStringOptions.omitYearIfCurrentOne
comment:
Specifies whether to omit the year from the resulting string when converting the Date object, if the year is the current one. This option takes precedence over useLongDateFormat . Examples

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to September 22, 2017, the resulting string does not contain the year (e.g., September 22).

  • If the Date object to convert is equivalent to September 22, 2016, the resulting string contains the year (e.g., September 22, 2016).

Default value is true.

name: IDateToStringOptions.predefinedFormat
comment:
Specifies a custom date format (e.g., dd/MM/yyyy), regardless of browser locale or any other option. This option uses the following syntax. All examples use the April 5th, 2018 14:15:34 time.

  • yyyy: full length year (e.g., 2018)
  • yy: short length year (e.g., 18)
  • MMMM: month name (e.g., April)
  • MMM: shortened month name (e.g., Apr)
  • MM: month number (e.g., 04)
  • M: single digit month number for months before October (e.g., 4)
  • dddd: day name (e.g., Thursday)
  • ddd: shortened day name (e.g., Thu)
  • dd: day number (e.g., 05)
  • d: single digit day for days before the 10th (e.g., 5)
  • hh: hour, in the 24-hour format (e.g., 14)
  • h: hour, in the 12-hour format (e.g., 2)
  • mm: minutes (e.g., 15)
  • ss: seconds (e.g., 34)

name: IDateToStringOptions.useLongDateFormat
comment: Specifies whether to format the resulting string in the long date format (e.g., Friday, August 04, 2017). Default value is false.

name: IDateToStringOptions.useTodayYesterdayAndTomorrow
comment:
Specifies whether to convert the Date object to the localized version of Today, Yesterday, or Tomorrow, if possible. This option takes precedence over useWeekdayIfThisWeek . Examples

If useTodayYesterdayAndTomorrow is true, and now contains a Date object equivalent to March 8, 2017, then:

  • If the Date object to convert contains a value equivalent to March 7, 2017, the resulting string is the localized version of Yesterday.

  • If the Date object to convert contains a value equivalent to March 8, 2017, the resulting string is the localized version of Today.

  • If the Date object to convert contains a value equivalent to March 9, 2017, the resulting string is the localized version of Tomorrow.

Default value is true.

name: IDateToStringOptions.useWeekdayIfThisWeek
comment:
Specifies whether to convert the Date object to the localized version of the corresponding day of the week, if the date to convert is part of the current week. This option takes precedence over omitYearIfCurrentOne . Examples

If useWeekdayIfThisWeek is true and now contains a Date object equivalent to Monday, March 8, 2017, then:

  • If the date to convert is equivalent to Saturday, March 6, 2017, the resulting string is the localized version of Last Saturday.

  • If the date to convert is equivalent to Thursday, March 11, 2017, the resulting string is the localized version of Next Thursday.

Default value is true.

name: IDisplayedNewResultEventArgs
comment: The IDisplayedNewResultEventArgs interface describes the object that all newResultDisplayed event handlers receive as an argument.

name: IDisplayedNewResultEventArgs.item
comment: The HTML element which was rendered by the the displayed result.

name: IDisplayedNewResultEventArgs.result
comment: The query result that was just displayed by the ResultList component.

name: IDisplayedNewResultsEventArgs
comment: The IDisplayedNewResultsEventArgs interface describes the object that all newResultsDisplayed event handlers receive as an argument.

name: IDisplayedNewResultsEventArgs.isInfiniteScrollEnabled
comment: Whether the results are being displayed in a ResultList with infinite scroll enabled. See enableInfiniteScroll option).

name: IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on QueryEvents.doneBuildingQuery

name: IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs.cancel
comment: If this property is set to true by any handlers, the query will not be executed.

name: IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs.queryBuilder
comment: Allow handlers to modify the query by using the QueryBuilder

name: IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs.searchAsYouType
comment: Whether the query is a search-as-you-type

name: IDuringQueryEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on QueryEvents.duringQuery

name: IDuringQueryEventArgs.promise
comment: A promises for the results that will be returned by the Search API

name: IDuringQueryEventArgs.query
comment: The query that was just executed

name: IDuringQueryEventArgs.queryBuilder
comment: The QueryBuilder that was used for the current query

name: IDuringQueryEventArgs.searchAsYouType
comment: Whether the query is a search-as-you-type

name: IEndpointCallOptions
comment: Available options when calling against the SearchEndpoint

name: IEndpointCallParameters
comment: Parameters that can be used when calling an EndpointCaller

name: IEndpointCallParameters.errorsAsSuccess
comment: Flag to specify if the endpoint should return different type of error as actual 200 success for the browser, but with the error code/message contained in the response.

name: IEndpointCallParameters.method
comment: Or HTTP verb : GET, POST, PUT, etc.

name: IEndpointCallParameters.queryString
comment:
Array of query string params.
eg: ['foo=1','bar=2']

name: IEndpointCallParameters.requestData
comment:
Body of the request.
key -> value map (JSON)

name: IEndpointCallParameters.requestDataType
comment:
Request data type.
eg: "application/json", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8"

name: IEndpointCallParameters.responseType
comment:
responseType of the request.
eg: "text", "arraybuffer" etc.

name: IEndpointCallParameters.url
comment: Url to target

name: IEndpointCallerOptions
comment: Possible options when creating a EndpointCaller

name: IEndpointCallerOptions.accessToken
comment: The access token to use for this endpoint.

name: IEndpointCallerOptions.password
comment:
The password to use to log into this endpoint. Used for basic auth.
Not used if accessToken is provided.

name: IEndpointCallerOptions.requestModifier
comment: A function which will allow external code to modify all endpoint call parameters before they are sent by the browser. Used in very specific scenario where the network infrastructure require special request headers to be added or removed, for example.

name: IEndpointCallerOptions.username
comment:
The username to use to log into this endpoint. Used for basic auth.
Not used if accessToken is provided.

name: IEndpointCallerOptions.xmlHttpRequest
comment: The XmlHttpRequest implementation to use instead of the native one. If not specified, the native one is used.

name: IErrorResponse
comment: An error response

name: IErrorResponse.data
comment: Data about the error

name: IErrorResponse.statusCode
comment: Status code for the error
